reviewText: A bit melodramatic-too bad they didn't spend more time on 1935-1945, the use of labor, the actual work done and the requirements of the regime, and the use by the US, Russia, and England of these scientists 1945-1970-would need 6-8 hours to do the work justice.

This program serves as an excellent introduction to WWII Germany's tech programs, the various efforts to obtain them and the controversy of using Nazis after the war. Being only an hour, you are only going to get so much depth here. Students of this subject may already be familiar with a lot of it, but there are new nuggets in here and its nice to have the visual info to go along with your studies. For more on these subjects, try Von Braun: Dreamer of Space, Engineer of War,Dark Side of the Moon: Wernher von Braun, the Third Reich, and the Space Race,Reich of the Black Sun: Nazi Secret Weapons & the Cold War Allied Legend &Hitler's Suppressed and Still-Secret Weapons, Science and Technology.

Secrets of the Dead - The Hunt for Nazi Scientists (2005) was a great five star made for TV special by PBS Home Video. It contained seldom if ever screened source footage of many famous and infamous German scientists and their weapon systems at the close of World War II.

If featured: the V-1 Flying Bomb and V-2 Rocket, the Messerschmitt 163 Rocket Plane and Messerschmitt 262 operational jet fighter which influenced the American Sabre Jet and Russian MIG 15 designs. It included rare footage of V-2 wind tunnel test models, films of production V-2's in their full color camouflage, test and operational footage of both the V-1 and V-2. It also featured footage of the German ME 163 rocket plane and 262 fighter jet.

Most interesting was the story of the efforts of the intelligence gathering forces of the allies to obtain equipment, designs and most important, the German scientists and engineers behind them. One unassuming army intelligence officer tells the very interesting tale of his activities to obtain as much of these as was possible for the United States while trying to avoid Russian agents who were on a similar mission. Other British intelligence officers are interviewed who stated that they saw the start of the cold war in the weeks following the conclusion of WWII with Germany.

The film included reenactments of the subject Army intelligence work and original old footage of von Braun and company doing their war related work for the Nazi's in Germany. Footage of von Braun from his surrender to the American Army are more than the usual brief clips and show him sporting the famous arm cast and smoking, looking a bit over-confident in himself, but obviously putting on a strong front.

This film featured some interesting interviews by camp workers who participated in the dark underbelly of the V-2 project who clearly stated that they could not understand von Braun being treated by America as a hero during the cold war.
